019package com.bewsoftware.utils.graphics;
020
021import java.awt.Graphics2D;
022import java.awt.Image;
023import java.awt.RenderingHints;
024import java.awt.Transparency;
025import java.awt.image.BufferedImage;
026import java.net.URL;
027import java.util.Objects;
028import javax.swing.ImageIcon;
029
030/**
031 * This class contains various static helper methods related to the
032 * manipulation of graphic images.
033 *
034 * @Note
035 * The code or ideas for these methods came mostly from the effort/work
036 * of others on the Internet. Recognition of their individual effort is
037 * primarily given in the JavaDoc comments attached to each method.
038 * This is usually in the form a link to the website page that was the
039 * source of the code/information.
040 *
041 * @author <a href="mailto:bw.opensource@yahoo.com">Bradley Willcott</a>
042 *
043 * @since 1.0.0
044 * @version 1.0.0
045 */
046public class ImageTools {
047
048    /**
049     * This class in not meant to be instantiated.
050     */
051    private ImageTools() {
052    }
053
054    /**
055     * Returns an ImageIcon, or {@code null} if the path was invalid.
056     * <p>
057     * Example:<br>
058     * <pre><code>
059     *     ImageIcon icon = createImageIcon(MyClass.class, "images/MyIcon.png", "My favourite picture");
060     * </code></pre>
061     * Method code sourced from :
062     * <a href="https://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/displayCode.html?code=https://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/uiswing/examples/components/IconDemoProject/src/components/IconDemoApp.java"
063     * target="_blank">Java Tutorials Code Sample â€“ IconDemoApp.java</a>
064     * <p>
065     * Modified the code to add the new first parameter: {@code t}. This allows the code to be
066     * further modified, making it into a {@code static} method of an external library class.
067     *
068     * @param <T>         class type of the calling instance.
069     * @param t           Usually should be the calling class, such as: {@code MyClass.class}.
070     * @param path        Image file path.
071     * @param description of icon.
072     *
073     * @return new icon, or {@code null} if not found.
074     */
075    public static <T> ImageIcon createImageIcon(Class<T> t, String path, String description) {
076        URL imgURL = t.getResource(path);
077
078        if (imgURL != null)
079        {
080            return new ImageIcon(imgURL, description);
081        } else
082        {
083            System.err.println("Couldn't find file: " + path);
084            return null;
085        }
086    }
087
088    /**
089     * Resizes an image using a Graphics2D object backed by a BufferedImage.
090     * <p>
091     * Method code sourced from:
092     * <a href="https://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/displayCode.html?code=https://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/uiswing/examples/components/IconDemoProject/src/components/IconDemoApp.java"
093     * target="_blank">Java Tutorials Code Sample â€“ IconDemoApp.java</a>
094     * <p>
095     * This code has been modified to incorporate code from:
096     * <a href="https://exceptionshub.com/java-image-resize-maintain-aspect-ratio.html"
097     * target="_blank">ExceptionsHub.com - Java image resize, maintain aspect ratio</a><br>
098     * Added preservation of aspect ratio, and changed the parameter names for {@code w}
099     * and {@code h}.
100     * <p>
101     * Further modification ideas came from:
102     * <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/244164/how-can-i-resize-an-image-using-java"
103     * target="_blank">How can I resize an image using Java?</a> and
104     * <a href="https://mkyong.com/java/how-to-resize-an-image-in-java/" target="_blank">
105     * How to resize an image in Java ?</a><br>
106     * Added Alpha preservation and additional {@code RenderingHints}.
107     *
108     * @param srcImg        source image to scale
109     * @param scaledWidth   desired width
110     * @param scaledHeight  desired height
111     * @param preserveAlpha Preserve Alpha - image with 8-bit RGBA color components
112     * @param preserveRatio Preserve aspect ratio?
113     *
114     * @return - the new resized image
115     */
116    public static Image getScaledImage(Image srcImg, int scaledWidth, int scaledHeight, boolean preserveAlpha, boolean preserveRatio) {
117        if (preserveRatio)
118        {
119            double imageHeight = srcImg.getHeight(null);
120            double imageWidth = srcImg.getWidth(null);
121
122            if (imageHeight / scaledHeight > imageWidth / scaledWidth)
123            {
124                scaledWidth = (int) (scaledHeight * imageWidth / imageHeight);
125            } else
126            {
127                scaledHeight = (int) (scaledWidth * imageHeight / imageWidth);
128            }
129        }
130
131        BufferedImage resizedImg = new BufferedImage(scaledWidth, scaledHeight,
132                                                     preserveAlpha ? BufferedImage.TYPE_INT_ARGB : BufferedImage.TYPE_INT_RGB);
133
134        Graphics2D g2 = resizedImg.createGraphics();
135        g2.setRenderingHint(RenderingHints.KEY_INTERPOLATION, RenderingHints.VALUE_INTERPOLATION_BILINEAR);
136        g2.setRenderingHint(RenderingHints.KEY_RENDERING, RenderingHints.VALUE_RENDER_QUALITY);
137        g2.setRenderingHint(RenderingHints.KEY_ANTIALIASING, RenderingHints.VALUE_ANTIALIAS_ON);
138        g2.drawImage(srcImg, 0, 0, scaledWidth, scaledHeight, null);
139        g2.dispose();
140
141        return resizedImg;
142    }
143
144    /**
145     * The fastest way to scale an image in java without losing image quality is
146     * to use Bilinear scaling. Bilinear is only good if you scale the image by
147     * 50% at a time because of the way it works. The following code is from
148     * "Filthy rich clients" by Chet Haase. He explains multiple techniques in
149     * the book, but this one has the highest performance to quality trade-off.
150     * <p>
151     * It supports all types of BufferedImages so don't worry about compatibility.
152     * It also lets java2D hardware accelerate your image because the calculations
153     * are done by Java2D. Don't worry if you don't understand that last part.
154     * The most important thing is that this is the fastest way to do it.
155     * <p>
156     * Method code and the above comments were sourced from:
157     * <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/3967731/how-to-improve-the-performance-of-g-drawimage-method-for-resizing-images/11371387#11371387"
158     * target="_blank">
159     * Stack Overflow - How to improve the performance of g.drawImage() method for
160     * resizing images</a>
161     *
162     * @param img                 Source image.
163     * @param targetWidth         Target width.
164     * @param targetHeight        Target height.
165     * @param progressiveBilinear Use Progressive Bilinear?
166     *
167     * @return the scaled image.
168     */
169    public static BufferedImage getFasterScaledInstance(BufferedImage img, int targetWidth, int targetHeight, boolean progressiveBilinear) {
170        int type = (img.getTransparency() == Transparency.OPAQUE)
171                   ? BufferedImage.TYPE_INT_RGB : BufferedImage.TYPE_INT_ARGB;
172        BufferedImage ret = img;
173        BufferedImage scratchImage = null;
174        Graphics2D g2 = null;
175        int w;
176        int h;
177        int prevW = ret.getWidth();
178        int prevH = ret.getHeight();
179
180        if (progressiveBilinear)
181        {
182            w = img.getWidth();
183            h = img.getHeight();
184        } else
185        {
186            w = targetWidth;
187            h = targetHeight;
188        }
189
190        do
191        {
192            if (progressiveBilinear && w > targetWidth)
193            {
194                w /= 2;
195                if (w < targetWidth)
196                {
197                    w = targetWidth;
198                }
199            }
200
201            if (progressiveBilinear && h > targetHeight)
202            {
203                h /= 2;
204                if (h < targetHeight)
205                {
206                    h = targetHeight;
207                }
208            }
209
210            if (scratchImage == null)
211            {
212                scratchImage = new BufferedImage(w, h, type);
213                g2 = scratchImage.createGraphics();
214            }
215
216            Objects.requireNonNull(g2).
217                    setRenderingHint(RenderingHints.KEY_INTERPOLATION,
218                                     RenderingHints.VALUE_INTERPOLATION_BILINEAR);
219            g2.drawImage(ret, 0, 0, w, h, 0, 0, prevW, prevH, null);
220            prevW = w;
221            prevH = h;
222            ret = scratchImage;
223        } while (w != targetWidth || h != targetHeight);
224
225        g2.dispose();
226
227        if (targetWidth != ret.getWidth() || targetHeight != ret.getHeight())
228        {
229            scratchImage = new BufferedImage(targetWidth, targetHeight, type);
230            g2 = scratchImage.createGraphics();
231            g2.drawImage(ret, 0, 0, null);
232            g2.dispose();
233            ret = scratchImage;
234        }
235
236        System.out.println("ret is " + ret);
237        return ret;
238    }
239}
